This is genuinely one of the very best rhythm games i've ever played, it has an amazing song list, amazing charts, amazing controls, and great characters. This is just a compilation of every other game in the series however they did not miss - i do have a few things i don't like which is 1 "removing the option to have manual fever AND automatic fever" and 2 "removing the arcade mode". I do also  kinda wish there was local multi player. but besides that, this is a GREAT rhythm game and i do seriously recommend it to anyone looking for it. Of course it does have a shop and a battle pass and ingame currency as well as always online drm so keep that in mind.

I've played this for 100 hours on another account, but it was in 4-button mode. When I bought the game again on this account, I decided to try it on 6-button. IT'S LIKE A WHOLE DIFFERENT GAME!

I was doing 10 difficulty on 4-button, but I had to start all the way back at 2 difficulty for 6-button. I think the point I'm trying to make is that this is the sort of game you can play forever. The skill ceiling is incredibly high. There are lots of different modes and ways to play. And tons of tunes. It's expensive, but if you love rhythm games, it's worth it.

One thing that makes DJMAX feel much better than some similar games (like Quaver, for instance) is the key sounds. Each button is mapped to an instrument in the song, which really makes it feel like you're playing along. I haven't played many other rhythm games that feel so tactile.
Strongly recommeded if you love music games and especially if you lvoe the DJ max series. You won't regret it.

This game is good, BUT you must be aware of a few things before you buy.

The game is a lot of fun; easily one of my favorite games. But I don't like the way this game monetizes itself. The base game is already expensive (so get it on sale if you can), and so is the DLC. On top of that, the game has a free currency you gain from playing, and a premium currency you pay real money for. Of course you can also buy the free currency if you want to. It's really only used for cosmetics, but that's important to some people. The in game store also cycles through items, which causes FOMO. I was lucky enough to see the only item I cared about when I had enough free currency to buy it. Not only that, but there is a season pass; a free one and a premium one. Once again, it's all cosmetics, but I know some people don't like season passes to begin with. Something else to consider is the premium season pass unlocks a bunch of songs, but you lose those songs once the season is over and have to buy their relevant DLC to play them again if you liked them.

Now for something a little less serious. Some songs don't have hit sounds. It was kind of jarring for me at first, but I got used to it. Keep in mind that a lot of the cheaper DLCs (or at least the ones I have) don't have hit sounds at all. Kind of to be expected, but that is something to be aware of when you make a purchase.

I was really teetering on whether or not I should recommend this game for a long time purely because the monetization made me feel concerned for certain kinds of people. I think that overall I do recommend it since most of it is just cosmetic, and the DLCs are purely optional.

A practically boundless font of creativity, both audio and visual. Maps are precise, and it is incredibly satisfying to chase perfect plays and high scores in a format that's accessible at home. The learning curve is gentle as well; starting out on 4 button 1* and 2* tracks will get you well on your way and at home with the controls, and the difficulty goes up 30 levels from there, including the Super Crazy (SC) difficulty tiers, and options to introduce more buttons to play as well. Lots of ways to customize your experience and bits like concept art to unlock, nameplates and the BGAs themselves, and a great variety of genres. DJMAX Respect V is, without question, one of the best rhythm experiences on PC.
